The goat of all games. Do yourself a favor and try it out, you won't regret it.
There are even tons of mods to make the game look more HD, if you can't stand the old school graphics.

I canâ€™t help but feel Iâ€™m missing out on something because every single positive review seems to be talking about a completely different game than the one I played. I should specify this is a review of the first 3 hours of the game (I couldnâ€™t bear it any further) from someone who is completely new to the series, unconcerned with its legacy. 

The graphics and overall presentation hold up fine. They would obviously be considered dated by todayâ€™s standards but theyâ€™re pleasant, if unremarkable, and donâ€™t break immersion.

The issue with Half-life is... well... everything else. 

The level design is shockingly bad from both an aesthetic and functional perspective. The muted greys of the facility are repetitive and boring and the game somehow fails to make a secret underground nuclear(?) military research base novel in any way. If vents turn you on youâ€™ll be hard as diamonds by the end of this game because the sheer amount of them is staggering. There are puzzles I suppose (I stacked a crate!) but the strongest puzzle is ultimately going to be finding a reason to continue playing. Few if any of the puzzles are engaging or challenging and feel more akin to busywork. 

The layout is twisting and bizarre to the point of having nothing in common with any real life building whatsoever. Its so shockingly so that it constantly breaks immersion and provides no sense of progression. It feels as if the player is merely tossed around different parts of some massive sprawling purgatorial corridor, never gaining a sense of whether theyâ€™re closer or not to the end goal (escape?).

Of course this would not be a complete non-issue if the shooting was the focus and the setting was just an excuse to get the to meat of the game (e.g. mario 64). However thatâ€™s not the case- clever storytelling through gameplay and environment are often touted as a major draw of the half life series. There are certainly instances of this - learning the military is in fact not there to help as you watch scientists gunned down from above, or seeing some poor soul dragged into a vent in the distance, foreshadowing the arrival of (yet more) headcrabs. But these instances are here and there and arenâ€™t interconnected in any interesting way. 

Furthermore the actual meat of the game (Puzzle solving, FPS gameplay) isâ€¦ passable at beast. The shooting is OK. I didnâ€™t expect much and it delivered wholesale on that expectation. The guns are generic dollar store military weapons and feel underwhelming to shoot.

Thereâ€™s very little in the way of mechanics or movement to learn, and the dominant strategy ultimately comes down to simply running past most enemies (the most pleasant way to play the game on hard). On the rare occasion however, the game flips the script and youâ€™re stuck between hordes of vortigaunt and the exit hoping you donâ€™t get insta force-lightninged to death while you wield the worst shotgun known to gaming history. Obviously this is 1998 so Iâ€™m not expecting current day AAA levels of feedback and tuning in the gunplay, but compared to something like Doom or even Marathon Half Lifeâ€™s gunplay canâ€™t hold a candle and feels phoned in.

The movement is clunky and has some weird kind of inertia to it. This wouldnâ€™t be a problem in your average FPS but the game is filled with an outrageous amount of platforming over instant death pits (Sometimes several in a row) meaning youâ€™ll be restarting at the same checkpoint over and over unless youâ€™re save scumming s.t.a.l.k.e.r. style. Another weird design choice in this vein is crouch jumping. Itâ€™s unclear to me why crouch jumping is so heavily implemented in the game. It feels janky and adds nothing whatsoever. Why not just let Freeman jump higher? 

The ladders make me want to blow my brains out. 

I canâ€™t say whether the story picks up later or not but the beginning has nothing to offer. The silent protagonist is a theoretical physicist who works with highly dangerous alien materials. This seems novel, and a welcome change from the characters that seem typical for the genre. But nope. Half life is just an cool man who kills aliens and doesnâ€™t afraid of anything. 

On hard the difficulty is inconsistent, ranging between easy (most segments with the soldiers) to extremely punishing (office with the vortigaunts), and the game rarely finds a way to slowly build up difficulty or create a skill curve. 

There are some novelties in this game, and those occur when the puzzles mesh with the combat, like leading superior numbers of enemies past a room filled with turrets while you dash behind the boxes to avoid getting shot. This is good fun and I imagine this is what made the game a hit, but for every one of these moments thereâ€™s another level segment filled with god awful platforming, crate stacking, and vents. 

Iâ€™d give it a 2/5 at best. There were things to like about it and itâ€™s clear the game was hugely influential but poor design choices and underwhelming FPS gameplay middle this title and prevent it from holding up alongside other FPS classics.

Where it all improved... Advanced AI, innovative HUD, engaging story, no cutscenes, gory gibs, large maps, advanced physics engine, damn good horror, cool creature design, silent protagonist and lots of crowbarring action. Half-Life 3's memic reputation and legendary status as the game to break all games is built on this game's legacy and status as a prime first-person shooter for the PC. Please Valve, learn to count to three (3).

It wasn't all too long, and was fun almost the entire way through.
The final boss was surprisingly easy, almost disappointingly so.
Spoiler warning after this point.
I'm assuming the final boss was so easy because as soon as I was getting less assault ammo, I started using something else to conserve it. Went into the boss armed to the teeth. After only a few deaths, I found that the fight was zap the crystals, then throw all the ammo I have into him while super-long-jumping around to avoid the one real attack he has. Duck behind pillars to avoid getting teleported, and the fight shouldn't take too long.

Half-Life is a classic game and a must play.  The game has aged alot and now feels odly nostalgic and charming with its low textures and weird sound effects, but it is surprisingly well optimized and is still very fun to play. I have never experienced a game that has aged so well and gracefully.  The game still runs quite fluently, I have encountered no technical issues or bugs.

Timeless masterpiece. The gameplay and graphics still holds up incredibly well to today and I enjoyed it like the first time. 

However, I came across a couple of glitches (like one where I kept being stuck inside a pipe after a loading screen or another related to the boss Gonarch) which I can't recall if they were in the original version but I wish they had fixed these for the Steam version.

this game is the worst thing to come out of that bottomless pit of disappointment called VALVe, the AI is non existent and has to use powerful weapons to do good, the puzzles are tedious and horrible, everything you'll here about this game is protected by nostalgia and the fact that most players haven't played it in years
